awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Eric Bates is "Asymptotics of Random Growth Models." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Alan Hammond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated properties of large random growth models and spin glasses.  These two families of disordered systems have broad mathematical interest and are relevant in a variety of other disciplines, including experimental physics, machine learning, and network theory.

Major outcomes include:

  • A new variational formula for the time constant in first-passage percolation.  This formula led to an affirmative answer to an open problem regarding convergence of the empirical measures of edge-weights witnessed along geodesics.
  • (joint work with Y. Sohn) A Parisi formula for the limiting free energy of multi-species spherical spin glasses, thereby synthesizing theories that had existed separately for single-species spherical models and multi-species non-spherical models. This Parisi formula was further transformed into its Crisanti–Sommers representation, analysis of which revealed a new physical phenomenon called simultaneous replica symmetry breaking.
  • (joint work with S. Ganguly and A. Hammond) Improved understanding of the directed landscape, which is a last-passage percolation model whose fractal geometry is purported to be universal among systems belonging to the Kardar–Parisi–Zhang class.  The rarity of certain non-unique geodesics was quantified by determining the Hausdorff dimension of the set of endpoints admitting such geodesics.
  • (joint work S. Chatterjee) A new form of localization exhibited by Gaussian disordered systems at low temperature.  These systems include directed polymers in Gaussian random environment, and many spin glass models.  In the context of directed polymers, the localization has a pathwise interpretation that was subsequently improved by the PI to apply along the entire polymer trajectory.  This geometric information was previously unknown.

The PI also engaged in numerous service activities enabled by the support of the postdoctoral fellowship.  These include mentorship of undergraduate research, organization of seminars and conferences, and K–12 educational outreach programs.
